newsitem.title: GERMANY: Cut overheads to boost jobs - German trade group.
newsitem.headline: Cut overheads to boost jobs - German trade group.

text.p: Germany must do more to lighten the cost load on employers if it is to make the shift to a modern service-led economy and cut record post-war unemployment, the head of a leading trade group said on Friday.
"If Germany does not become a service economy, it will go under," Michael Fuchs, president of the Federal Association of Wholesalers and Exporters (BGA), told a news conference.

He said modest cuts in welfare overheads recently enacted by Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government were too small and had not yet fed through to companies, which would also be hit by a cabinet decision on Thursday to hike pension charges.
And he hit back at this week's attack by Kohl's parliamentary right-hand man Wolfgang Schaeuble that employers had "glaringly failed" to create new jobs thanks to the government measures.
"It is wrong to attack employers as though the cost burden had already been lifted. It hasn't happened yet," Fuchs said.

Kohl's centre-right coalition recently passed a package of welfare cuts, including reducing sick pay, but trade unions are fiercely defending hard-won entitlements written into their collective pay deals.
Fuchs criticised politicians for concentrating too much on traditional industries which drove Germany's post-war economic miracle, and ignoring the underdeveloped service sector.

Germany lost 825,000 industrial jobs between 1989 and 1995, while 1.6 million were created in the services sector. Services now account for 50 percent of gross domestic product; industry just 35 percent, he said.
But, in comparison with the U.S., which employs 75 percent of workers in services, Germany lags with just 61 percent.
Hopes for reducing Germany's four million jobless total depend on opening the way for service companies to operate in a deregulated environment, Fuchs said.
That would require opening up Germany's collective pay bargaining system to allow the creation of lower-paid jobs.
Fuchs, noting that Germany's unemployment rate, at over 10 percent, was double that in the U.S., said that even so-called "McJobs" were better than long-term unemployment.

That view was not shared by Margret Moenig-Raane, head of the HBV white-collar trade union, who told reporters she would not accept changes to the collective pay bargaining structure and wanted to keep full sick pay benefits.
"It is unbelievably naive to say that reducing sick pay will help to create jobs," Moenig-Raane said.
"If the wholesale sector wants to become a stronger service provider in future, it should not demotivate workers through the social standards of primitive capitalism," she added.

Despite their differing views, the BGA and HBV began a two-day conference on Friday to try and find common ways to tackle Germany's jobs crisis. They said they hoped then to present joint proposals for action to Chancellor Kohl.
